case_name: M/s. J. Burman Co. v. Union of India

facts.text: Union of India filed a petition in the Court of the First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against M/s. J. Burman Co.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Union of India, filed a petition in the Court of the First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against the appellant M s. J. Burman Co., through its proprietor Jawahar Lal Burman under sections 33 and 28 of the Act.

facts.text: Contract entered into between parties on August 31, 1949 for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of coconut oil by appellant to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent alleged that a concluded contract had been entered into between the parties on August 31, 1949 for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of coconut oil by the appellant to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent advertised in the Indian Trade Journal for supply of coconut oil.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had advertised in the Indian Trade Journal for he said supply and the appellant had submitted its tender No. SM-I/104524.

facts.text: Appellant submitted tender No. SM-I/104524.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant had submitted its tender No. SM-I/104524. This tender was accepted by the respondent which concluded a contract between the parties.

facts.text: Tender accepted by respondent, concluding contract governed by conditions in Form W.S.B. 133 including arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: This tender was accepted by the respondent which concluded a contract between the parties. The respondents case was that the said contract was governed by general conditions of contract Form W. S. B. 133.

facts.text: Disputes arose between parties regarding the contract.

anchor.surface_text: These conditions included an arbitration agreement. Disputes arose between the parties regarding the said contract, and so in pursuance of the arbitration agreement they were referred to the two arbitrators appointed by the parties.

facts.text: Disputes referred to two arbitrators appointed by the parties.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose between the parties regarding the said contract, and so in pursuance of the arbitration agreement they were referred to the two arbitrators appointed by the parties.

facts.text: Appellant objected to arbitrators' jurisdiction claiming no concluded contract.

anchor.surface_text: After the arbitration proceedings had gone on for a considerable time before the arbitrators the appellant objected to their jurisdiction to deal with the disputes on the ground that there was no concluded contract between the parties.

facts.text: Respondent moved court for decision on existence and validity of arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: This plea made it necessary for the respondent to move the Court for a decision of the question about the existence and validity of the arbitration agreement.

facts.text: Petition under sections 28 and 33 sought declaration of concluded contract with valid arbitration agreement and extension of time for arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: It was on these allegations that the respondent in its petition claimed that it may be held that there was a concluded contract between the parties containing a valid arbitration agreement. The petition having been made under section 28 along with section 33 the respondent prayed that suitable extension of time be granted to the arbitrators for making the award.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded no concluded contract and no court jurisdiction under section 28.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded in defence that no concluded contract had been made between the parties and that there was no jurisdiction in the Court to grant extension under section 28. The other allegations made by the respondent in its petition were also traversed.

facts.text: Trial judge found concluded contract, valid arbitration agreement, court jurisdiction, declared valid reference, granted one month's extension to arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: He found that a concluded contract had been proved between the parties as alleged by the respondent, that there was a valid arbitration agreement in the said contract and that the Court had jurisdiction to try the petition. ... Consequently he granted a months time to the arbitrators to make their award.

facts.text: No specific point raised by appellant on lack of jurisdiction under section 33 or 32 before trial judge.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally it may be pointed out at this stage that no specific point had been raised in the pleadings of the appellant that the Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the petition under section 33 or section 32 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision petition in High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh challenging trial court decision.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was challenged by the appellant by its revision petition preferred in the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh.

facts.text: High Court confirmed trial court's finding of concluded contract containing arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has confirmed the finding of the trial court that there was a concluded contract which contained an arbitration agreement.

facts.text: High Court held petition under sections 28 and 33 competent, dismissed appellant's revision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, held that since the petition has been filed as a composite application under sections 28 and 33 it was open to the Court under section 28 to enter upon the question of the existence or validity of the contract and so there was no substance in the point of jurisdiction raised by the appellant. In the result the appellants revision application was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of sections 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 (10 of 1940) hereafter called the Act.

facts.text: Arbitration proceedings went on for considerable time before arbitrators heard the matter at length.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent nominated their arbitrators. The arbitrators heard the matter at length and the proceedings had reached a stage when an award might have been pronounced.

facts.text: Appellant refused to apply under section 33, causing stalemate in arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Even then he refused to apply under section 33 and so a stalemate ensued because the arbitrators were not entitled to proceed further with the arbitration proceedings in view of the point raised by the appellant.

facts.text: Acceptance letter dated August 31, 1949 stated offer accepted for 1704 Cwts. and 2 qrs. of coconut oil at Rs. 89/6/- per Cwt., delivery ex-godown Calcutta by 39-9-49, subject to depositing 10% security.

anchor.surface_text: In this letter written on August 31, 1949 the respondent stated as follows Dear Sirs, Ref - Your tender No. and date Nil. Your offer is hereby accepted for a quantity of 1704 Cwts. and 2 qrs. ... subject to your depositing 10 as security.

facts.text: Security deposit Rs. 15,230/- to be deposited immediately, contract concluded by this acceptance, formal acceptance on receipt of treasury receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The security money which comes to Rs. 15,230/- ... should please be deposited immediately into a Government Treasury ... The contract is concluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt.

facts.text: Tender subject to conditions in Form W.S.B. 133, security deposit condition subsequent not precedent.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the tender thus submitted was subject to the conditions of contract governing the Department of Supply Contracts which were set out in the Government Publication Form W. S. B. 133.

facts.text: Supreme Court held trial court had jurisdiction under section 32 impliedly, petition competent.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the petition made by the respondent was competent under section 32 of the Act and has been properly entertained by the trial Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was a concluded contract between parties.

anchor.surface_text: reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below have erred in coming to the conclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance of the tender or offer made by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended acceptance letter made security deposit condition precedent, no concluded contract.

anchor.surface_text: His argument is that the material words used in the acceptance letter changed the pre-existing position and made the security deposit a condition precedent to the acceptance itself. If this contention is right it would necessarily mean that there was no concluded contract.

issues.text: The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of sections 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of sections 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940  10 of 1940   hereafter called the Act . That question arises in this way. The respondent, Union of India, filed a petition in the Court of the First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against the appellant M s. J. Burman Co., through its proprietor Jawahar Lal Burman under sections 33 and 28 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the respondent’s petition

anchor.surface_text: He contends that the High Court was in error in holding that the trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the respondent’s petition, and he argues that even if the point of jurisdiction raised by him fails it should be held that there was no concluded contract between the parties and so there was no scope or room for making any reference to arbitration.

issues.text: The question which we have to consider is whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of section 33

anchor.surface_text: The question which we have to consider is whether a person affirming an arbitration agreement can apply under the latter part of section 33. Even assuming that the requirement that an application can be made under the first part of section 33 only by persons desiring to challenge the arbitration agreement does not apply to its latter part, it is difficult to hold that an application to have the effect of the arbitration agreement determined can legitimately cover the dispute as to the existence of the said arbitration agreement.

issues.text: what remedy it is open to a party to adopt in order to obtain an appropriate declaration about the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: The bar to the suit thus created by section 32 inevitably raises the question as to what remedy it is open to a party to adopt in order to obtain an appropriate declaration about the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement and it is on the decision of this question that the parties are at issue before us.

issues.text: That takes us to the next question as to whether there was a concluded contract between the parties or not

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the next question as to whether there was a concluded contract between the parties or not. We have already noticed that in response to the advertisement published by the respondent in the Indian Trade Journal the appellant submitted its tender.

issues.text: whether an application can be made under such inherent jurisdiction for a declaration that the contract which includes the arbitration agreement as defined by section 2(a)

anchor.surface_text: Even if it is held that there is inherent jurisdiction in the Court to entertain an application in support of the existence of an arbitration agreement the question still remains whether an application can be made under such inherent jurisdiction for a declaration that the contract which includes the arbitration agreement as defined by section 2(a) includes cases where the arbitration agreement is made a part of the contract itself.

arguments.claim: Section 32 bars suits affirming existence or validity of arbitration agreement just as it bars challenges

anchor.surface_text: Thus there can be no doubt, that if a party affirms the existence of an arbitration agreement or its validity it is not open to the party to file a suit for the purpose of obtaining a declaration about the existence of the said agreement or its validity. Such a suit in terms is barred by section 32.

arguments.claim: The bar under section 32 implies a remedy by application to avoid anomalous result of no remedy for affirming party

anchor.surface_text: unless it is held that the creation of the said absolute bar itself involves the right to make an application under the Act it would lead to the anomalous result that a party is given no remedy

arguments.claim: Sections 31, 32, 33 must be read harmoniously to permit applications under section 32 for affirmations

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the scheme of sections 31, 32 and 33 it would not be unreasonable to hold that in matters which fall within the bar created by section 32 if a suit cannot be filed it is necessarily intended that an application can be made

arguments.claim: Legislative purpose of sections 32-33 is to prevent abuse of process by requiring petitions not suits

anchor.surface_text: Before the present Act was passed experience showed that unscrupulous and dishonest parties to the arbitration agreements frequently chose to deny the existence of the said agreements even after the arbitration proceedings had concluded and ended in awards

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act has no material bearing on the decision of this point. The power to enlarge-time for making the award which is the subject-matter of the provisions of section 28 cannot be held to include a power to entertain petitions like the present.

holdings.text: Section 32 bars suits for declaration affirming the existence or validity of an arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there can be no doubt, that if a party affirms the existence of an arbitration agreement or its validity it is not open to the party to file a suit for the purpose of obtaining a declaration about the existence of the said agreement or its validity. Such a suit in terms is barred by section 32.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of section 32's wide bar 'on any ground whatsoever' applies equally to affirmations as challenges.

holdings.text: A party affirming the existence of an arbitration agreement cannot apply under section 33.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it seems to us that a party affirming the existence of an arbitration agreement cannot apply under section 33 for obtaining a decision that the agreement in question exists. In fairness we ought to add that the learned Solicitor-General,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 33 first part for challenges; latter part for 'effect' distinct from 'existence'; otherwise first part superfluous.

holdings.text: The bar under section 32 implies a remedy by application under the Act for affirmations of existence/validity.

anchor.surface_text: unless it is held that the creation of the said absolute bar itself involves the right to make an application under the Act it would lead to the anomalous result that a party is given no remedy to enforce the right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.31-33 avoids anomaly of no remedy; legislature cannot intend unreasonable result.

holdings.text: Applications affirming arbitration agreements can be made under court's powers impliedly recognized by section 32.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the scheme of sections 31, 32 and 33 it would not be unreasonable to hold that in matters which fall within the bar created by section 32 if a suit cannot be filed it is necessarily intended

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of ss.31-33; aligns with ss.20,33 where affirmations possible; avoids stalemate.

holdings.text: Section 28 does not confer jurisdiction to decide existence/validity of arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act has no material bearing on the decision of this point. The power to enlarge-time for making the award which is the subject-matter of the provisions of section 28 cannot be held to include

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.28 limited to time extension; cannot include entertaining petitions on existence.

holdings.text: Petition competent under section 32 even seeking declaration on main contract where challenge common to contract and arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: the fact that an incidental declaration is claimed about the existence and validity of the main contract does not affect the essential character of the application. It is an application for obtaining a declaration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form; challenge to contract implies challenge to included arbitration agreement; barred by s.32.

holdings.text: Trial court had jurisdiction; petition under s.32 competent.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the petition made by the respondent was competent under section 32 of the Act and has

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court (different reasons); implied jurisdiction under s.32.

holdings.text: There was a concluded contract between the parties containing valid arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below have erred in coming to the conclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance of the tender or offer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance letter whole read unqualified per s.7 Contract Act; security deposit condition subsequent per Form WSB 133.

holdings.text: Security deposit is a condition subsequent, not precedent, to contract formation.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus obvious that the tender offered by the appellant submitted to these terms and that on these terms security deposit is a condition subsequent and not a condition precedent. Clause 4 b

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses 4(a),(b) Form W.S.B.133; acceptance letter consistent, not varying to precedent.

holdings.text: Bombay High Court decision in M. Gulamali substantially correct on inherent jurisdiction under s.32.

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to think that the decision of the Bombay High Court is substantially correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Aligns with court's interpretation; contrasts Calcutta views.

precedents.citation: Hayman v. Darwins, Ltd.  1942 A. C. 356. S. C. 1942 1 All. E. R. 337 at p. 347

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Lord Macmillan in Hayman v. Darwins, Ltd.  1942 A. C. 356. S. C. 1942 1 All. E. R. 337 at p. 347 , the arbitration clause is quite distinct from the other clauses. The other clauses set out the obligations which the parties undertake towards each other hinc inde but the arbitration clause does number impose on one of the parties an obligation in favour of the other. It embodies the agreemen

precedents.cited_proposition: arbitration clause is distinct from other contract clauses as it does not impose obligations on one party to another but provides for dispute settlement by arbitration and can be specifically enforced
precedents.cited_holding: the arbitration clause is quite distinct from the other clauses [...] the arbitration clause can be specifically enforced by the machinery of the Arbitration Acts

precedents.citation: Messrs. M. Gulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya  I. L. R. 1950 Bom. 333

anchor.surface_text: In Messrs. M. Gulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya  I. L. R. 1950 Bom. 333  a petition had been filed for a declaration that the respondents had entered into the contract with the petitioners for purchase of 500 bars of silver on or about January 30, 1948 according to the rules and regulations of the Marwari Chamber of Commerce, Ltd., and that the respondents were bound to have all disputes in connection with the same contract decided by the arbitrators as provided by the said rules and regulations. The competence of this petition and the jurisdiction of the Court to entertain it were disputed. Both the learned trial judge and the Court of Appeal rejected the respondents contention and held that there was an inherent jurisdiction in the Court to entertain petitions in respect of matters covered by the bar raised by section 32.

precedents.case_name: Messrs. M. Gulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya
precedents.cited_proposition: court has inherent jurisdiction to entertain petitions declaring existence of contract containing arbitration agreement, despite bar under section 32

precedents.citation: Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers  A. I. R. 1950 Cal. 267

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers  A. I. R. 1950 Cal. 267  as well as in State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., Ltd.  I. L. R. 1952 2 Cal. 49 , a contrary view has been accepted. In the latter case, a suit had been filed on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court claiming a declaration that a certain contract was not made between the parties and was not binding on the plaintiff. A further claim was also made that it should be declared that the defendant was not entitled to make any claim in respect of the said contract and that the contract be adjudged void and delivered up as cancelled. The learned trial judge construed the plaint as one for declaration that the arbitration agreement contained in the contract was invalid and on that view he held that under sections 32 and 33 of the Act the suit was not maintainable. On appeal it was held that the suit was not one for challenging the validity of the arbitration agreement merely it covered other reliefs and so bar of sections 32 and 33 could not be pleaded.

precedents.cited_proposition: suit challenging contract not barred by sections 32 and 33 if not merely challenging validity of arbitration agreement

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., Ltd.  I. L. R. 1952 2 Cal. 49

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Bajranglal Laduram v. Agarwal Brothers  A. I. R. 1950 Cal. 267  as well as in State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co., Ltd.  I. L. R. 1952 2 Cal. 49 , a contrary view has been accepted. In the latter case, a suit had been filed on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court claiming a declaration that a certain contract was not made between the parties and was not binding on the plaintiff. A further claim was also made that it should be declared that the defendant was not entitled to make any claim in respect of the said contract and that the contract be adjudged void and delivered up as cancelled. The learned trial judge construed the plaint as one for declaration that the arbitration agreement contained in the contract was invalid and on that view he held that under sections 32 and 33 of the Act the suit was not maintainable. On appeal it was held that the suit was not one for challenging the validity of the arbitration agreement merely it covered other reliefs and so bar of sections 32 and 33 could not be pleaded. We are inclined to think that the decision of the Bombay High Court is substantially correct.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: suit for declaration that no contract existed and not binding, seeking cancellation, not barred by sections 32 and 33 as not merely challenging arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold, though for different reasons, that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the petition made by the respondent was competent under section 32 of the Act and has been properly entertained by the trial Court. This question has been the subject-matter of some judicial decisions

outcome.relief_summary: Upheld High Court and trial court findings on jurisdiction under section 32 and existence of concluded contract with valid arbitration agreement; rejected appellant's contentions
